reviews.review_text: A missed opportunity. That's all I can call it.   NS2 isn't a bad game. In fact, despite not personally recommending it, I still think it is a good game. The problem is that it isn't a game I can recommend to others. If you look at my hours I'm not someone who hasn't given the game a chance. In fact, I beta tested the original NS1 mod. When NS2 was announced and they asked for help to fund it, I purchased a few copies of Zen of Sudoku (another game they produced). Then, when they were near finished NS2, I pre-purchased the game, sight unseen, long before release.   So I do support the game and the makers. I just can't recommend it anymore. Why? Well the answer can be found in the game's development.  The big failure of the game is exactly what happened with NS1. Basically the developers allowed a small--but vocal and intolerant--minority of players dictate the direction of gameplay development. These 'pros', are basically the people and clanners who play games competitively and/or in tournaments. Now I can see wanting to appeal to the 'pro' gamers as a means to generate interest, but there needs to be a balance between competitive and casual play. Sadly, there never was.   In the end, the difficulty and learning curve puts this game well out of reach of all but the veterans. New players are quickly steamrolled and wonder how the heck it happened. What's worse is that they released the game without a trainer or tutorial mode. While there is a basic 'sandbox' mode that helps to get a player acclimated to the game before they play, it's too little too late.  I saw this all happen in NS1, and it saddened me when it happened here. The competitive gamers basically co-opt the game, and casual players are forced to play at that high level or they don't play at all. In my opinion, the logical way to develop the game would have been to introduce a 'tournament mode', with increased difficulty, for those dedicated players. It could have been finely tuned to appeal directly to their form of play, while still leaving the game with a 'casual' player base that could actually play the game. Unfortunately, the developers objected to this concept suggesting they didn't want there to be 'two games'. But the reality is that difficulty levels are part of gaming. That doesn't make it 'two games', it makes it one game with two difficulty levels.   With the development team basically abandoning casual players, this basically meant that no matter how many sales they made, the new players never stuck around. If you look at the history of the game, you will see that from the release in late October 2012 until the end of 2012, there was a large player base that bought the game and was playing. Since everyone was still learning, it meant there was the potential for developers to cater to that casual player base and build their numbers further. Instead, they went the other way, abandoning the casual player base in favor of the competitive and tournament players.  Over on Steamcharts you can see just how the game started strong and then flamed out in a spectacular fashion. (  steamcharts.com/app/4920  ) The all-time peak number of players online was just a bit shy of 10K. At time of writing there were ~200 playing. It's sad, it really is, since this could have been a much better overall game.  The nail in the coffin for this game was when development for 'game balance' was put in the hands of volunteers. Since the game is easy to modify (in the LUA scripts), balance changes didn't have to be hard coded into the game. As such, a bunch of people who felt they 'knew better' how the game should be developed were able to markedly influence balance changes by verbally bullying anyone who disagreed with them. Anyone who dared question those who wanted to make the game harder were verbally ridiculed and harassed. The game forums became toxic as a result, and casual players began their exodus.   Well, those competitive players got what they wanted. The game is exactly how they said it should be balanced. It's too bad there is hardly anyone left playing now.   What's worse is that the more appealing elements of the game--the highest level 'upgrades'--only show up when the outcome of the game is predetermined. (which happens within the first few minutes) Users who look and see the marine 'mech' robots and the 'rhino-size' alien don't realize that they will likely rarely if ever get to play them.   This game is a good example of what *not* to do when developing a game. While I can see the appeal of competitive gaming to a game like this, it can't be at the expense of casual gamers. Otherwise you kill the potential for the game to grow. Look at TF2. A game that is 'easy', but that can be hard based on the skill of the players. That could have been how NS2 ended up. Instead, the game is harder than ever. What's worse is that they added a ranking system to which isolates players based on skill. New players will find game choices limited as a result.  Simple example of a poor balance choice? In TF2, if you need to get health, you can pick up health kits (on the field or in spawn) and also be healed by the doctor. In NS2 it used to be you could go to 'spawn' and heal up fully (health and armor) at the armory--like a med cabinet in TF2 spawn--and you could get health-only medkit drops in the field. If one was away from spawn, armor could only be repaired with a welder. (like a medigun, except anyone could carry one if they bought it.) However, the competitive complainers cabal (I love alliteration) pressured the person doing balance work to make it so the armory would no longer heal players. In other words, once you lost armor you needed to be welded, and you can't weld yourself--other players have to do it. The outcome of this change was that it made it that much harder for players to stay alive unless they are highly skilled.   In the end, I still play NS2, and I would recommend it to anyone who I felt had the skill to survive. However, there aren't very many people who fit that description.   Unless you are someone who considers themselves an exceptionally good FPS player, I would advise you give the game a pass unless it is deeply discounted and you're willing to take the chance the game may not be fun for you.   While NS2 is--on the surface--a good game, it missed its chance to be a great one.

My all-time favorite multiplayer FPS.  At this point, balance is about as even as it's going to get for an FPS with asymmetrical teams, and the developers (both Unknown Worlds and the Community Dev Team) have added a significant amount of content in a number of rather sizable updates. The community is still quite active and is far less dickish than most, which, to me, is a rarity in this age of games going out of style once they're no longer the flavor of the month.  The gameplay, while obviously an FPS, is very much dependent upon the strategic layer, and vice versa. What this means is that the commander's role is absolutely vital to the success of the players on foot, and their capability to win their encounters affects whether or not he can expand; it's not like Nuclear Dawn or some other RTS/FPS hybrids where one element is gimped or neutered while the other is fleshed out.  My only complaint would be the devs' tendency to change things unnecessarily every other week, with minor balance patches or changes throwing the whole game out of whack. The game as it is now is NOT the same game it was at launch, not by a long shot. If you can keep pace with the changes and roll with the punches, however, it's excellent fun.  One crucial tip for new players would be to use your microphone, if you have one (I know you do). Communication with your team is key. Don't be afraid to pipe up on voice, and always keep an eye on your map (bound to the C key by default).

I can’t believe I haven’t reviewed this game yet after 150+ hours into it. But I have returned from a long hiatus to play this game and again and I thought it was time for a review. In a world filled with boring repetitive multiplayer shooters where you run around like a chicken with their head cut off comes a game like Natural Selection 2. A game that ACTUALLY understands the point of competitive multiplayer. TO WORK AS A TEAM!  You play as Aliens or Marines. The marines are fairly standard and easy to get the hang of. For the most part I’m a rather good marine player. Aliens are trickier and require more practice. While I’m not a great alien player I’m decent-ish. In other words I still manage to get more than 5 kills. Overall the game requires teamwork and strategy opposed to lone wolfing it. If you run off on your own you will die. You need to be supported by your team members. Also the game is farily well balanced as I did not notice any major balance issues.   Highly recommended: 9/10 Great game.

There aren't as many servers as there used to be but it's still no problem to find active games with enough players. This game is definitely worth it and its usually on sale. There are 2 playable factions -humans and aliens and each have their own special units and abilities. The amazing thing about this game is that its very teamwork intensive. Each team gets 1 commander who pretty much gets an overhead view of the battlefield and instructs teammates on what to do/build. The game is pretty easy for humans but for aliens its a big learning curve. If you do get the game do not play commander without reading a guide/tutorial because it can be extremely difficult. The combat is very fun and you can do all types of strategies and builds each game, such as fast expand for aliens to get xenomorph or human fast expand with warp gate tech or harassing human extractors with skulks with aliens which is one of the best ways to get yourself back into the game as aliens.  All in all 9/10 Very good game I would recommend.

I've read many reviews complaining about an update that moved server-lists to a different, clearly visible, tab. I have to say that after purchasing this game I honestly believed that my experience would be mediocre at best: Veterans calling out noobs, discouraging them to continue playing, etc. Not once in my short period of owning this game has this happened. (I'm willing to rule out that I'm lucky and just haven't been around 'those' people).  However, I can tell you this: As an achievement hunter, I was able to contact a developer on the official discord server (Remi, you're awesome!). This person took the time out to help me join a private server full of veterans for a 'Captain's Night' (Shout out to TGNS, you folks are great and I hope to play with you all again!) and was nice about it. Not only that, but the folks I played with were all immensely supportive of a 'greenie' being on their side. Folks in the voice-comms were giving me tips, telling me to follow them around, and showing me some really neat tricks.  I personally like small maps with 7v7 teams; it allows you to know the folks you're playing with (especially if they are in comms). I've had a great experience so far.  TLDR; This game is awesome and I highly recommend it for the experience and the community.

I have played many many hours with Natural Selection 2 and for the most part, I have greatly enjoyed my experience. My feelings about it are very complex, as it's a bold and innovative step in FPS multiplayer, has excellent developer support, and a pretty good community to boot. There are frequent updates and gameplay balances, and a new map is released roughly every six months or so. The two opposing factions are assymetrically balanced and gameplay is varied and interesting. So much so that you don't mind playing the same few maps over and over again countless times. In some respects, this game has pretty much everything going for it.   Sadly, I simply cannot recommend Natural Selection 2 for one very specific reason. The game's greatest strength is its ability to seamlessly blend the RTS experience with the FPS experience, and when you have a team that works well together, under a commander who knows the ropes, this game offers one of the most fun multiplayer experiences available.   It is this same strength which is also the game's greatest flaw. Very often - almost always - your experience is entirely dependant on the person in the command chair. To begin with, no one ever wants to be commander. You will sometimes spend as much as 10 minutes waiting for someone's patience to wear thin enough that they finally get into the command chair, at which point you are at their mercy. Sometimes you will even spend longer waiting for the commander than the actual game lasts.   If this person happens to be you, your command experience will go one of three ways: 1) You will do an excellent job and everyone will love you for it, in which case your game will likely be over very quickly. 2) You will do an excellent job and everyone will hate you for it anyway, because you didn't build X thing at Y time. They will complain at you for arbitrary reasons, even though you are winning the game. 3)You will do a bad job and everyone will hate you for it, likely resulting in you being kicked from the command position, ostricized, and ruining everyone's fun.   Additionally, while the game is quite expertly balanced, it takes very little to upset that balance. A bad or good commander can mean everything in a game, and very often the fun and enjoyment of as many as 24 people hinges on that commander's ability to play the game. It's not uncommon to spend hours going from stacked game to stacked game because teams just can't seem to turn out right. And then, when that magical golden ratio finally occurs, and the game looks like it's going to be a long, bloody, brutal fight to the death, someone rushes your base and the game is over before you have time to check the map.   So, while I have had some real fun with Natural Selection 2, at the end of the day I just can't recommend a game with such a massive, fundamental, and irreversible flaw. The average player just has to put in way too much effort and patience to squeeze the fun out of this game. But I do admit that if you manage to do so, you will be in for quite a treat.

Damn solid multiplayer game. Although the learning curve is pretty tremendous for what seems to be a simple AVP concept, the reality is that Natural Selection 2 involves requiring strategy that most games do not. Each of the two teams of Aliens and Marines have one commander, a person who assumes a top view of the map and can order his soldiers to go to a certian location, complete an objective, upgrade their armor and weaponry, and build structures to fortify the main base and make their team more powerful. I have found that the community for NS2 is generally helpful to rookies, and most (not all) will give tips and advise to new players struggling with the heavy expectations for a team in the matches that can last upwards of half an hour. Occasionally you witness the gruff veteran who lacks patience for the new recruits, but you can pick up on the game mechanics fairly quickly before they nag at you consistently. The gameplay is solid and balanced, playing as either team is fun and enjoyable. Playing as the vulnerable aliens as you stalk your prey can be exhilierating, but hunting the agile opponets with a pulse rifle can be equally enjoyable. The best game involves high levels of cooperation for all, but when you win, it feels great to have contributed to a team and I think I can say the level of comradery felt between two people is greatest when you squinting in the dimly light power room trying to reconstruct power to get the lights on as knee-high aliens shoot acidic goo at your feet. Fantastic game at any price, and it is gaurenteed to last you quite a while.

If you can manage to power through the steep learning curve, you are rewarded with one of the most entertaining and interesting FPS games out there.

Natural Selection 2 is a near-perfect asymmetrical multiplayer game that integrates the real-time strategy and first-person shooter genres into one package. In Natural Selection 2, there are two teams: the marines, and the aliens. The marines work kind of like your typical first-person shooter. They are, however, led by a commander who can drop health and ammo for the marines as well as placing structures around the map for them to build on their quest for victory. The aliens work a little differently; they tend to fight more effectively in close quarters situations, unlike the marines who can shoot from a distance. The alien players can also evolve into more advanced life forms whom each have their own advantages and disadvantages. Just like the marines, the aliens have a commander. The alien commander works much more independently than the marine commander; however, the alien commander can still provide a lot of support for his team with the structues that he or she builds and the upgrade paths that he or she chooses. The asymmetrical gameplay along with the combination of two outstanding game genres means that there is never really a dull moment, as every match can be interesting in its own way. I definitely recommend that you atleast give Natural Selection 2 a chance.

As a Half-Life fan, I heard of this mod long time ago - but never played it. Lately, I gave NS2 a second chance and must admit that they put great effort into updates. You can use raw mouse input and the performance has increased dramatically. Furthermore the skill level is quite high (I think there is a competitive scene) and it is really fun to fool around as a total noob on public servers.  The aiming skills needed are different (in comparision to e. g. Counter-Strike) because aliens are very fast, can be nearly everywhere and a lot of close combat situations arise. The RTS part of the game (commanding) seems to introduce a lot of cooperation and teamwork even to public servers.  There are always full servers and the community is surprisingly friendly (voice communication is quite common). This is a great game, worth to buy even at full price - if you have time to play.

Quite a fun game. I offers 2 gameplay modes, one is a standard FPS like mode where you play as one of the human squad members, and the other as one of th ealines. Each one of the factions (human/alien) has its own different unit types, and heavy units. The second mode is the commander mode in which only one player plays the game in a top down view, simmilar to Real Time Strategies. The commander can place 'building blueprints', which then the team can construct, in order to gain additional upgrades (ammo/armor and so forth), There are additional upgrades/buildings that let the teams build/construct their ultimate units - a big mech, and a huge rhino like alien. The commander can also drop ammo and health packs for his troops (if he has enough resources), that aer gained by expansing the team's control over the map and building harvesters. The play style of both aliens and humans are bit diffrent. While the humans favor conventional guns and stationary projectile turrets, the aliens usually domiinate in up close meely combat...and flying units.   Overall this game is rather enjoyable, and offers a nice change of pace. If you get bored of the FPS portion, you can play as a commander, and get into the strategic view. The community seems to work rather well together, reminiscent of the old days BF2 (real team play) gameplay, where people support one another, and have helpful roles.

Okay. Like the Alien Trilogy? Like actual teamwork. Want an actually friendly community? Like the sound of xenomorphic teeth ripping through space marine armor? Like feeling like like the STATE OF THE BADASS ART? GET THIS GAME.  Down to its core, NS2 is a game of teamwork. Two asymetrical teams fight to the death for the future of their species. This isn't an average FPS. Both teams, the human Frontiersman and the alien Kharaa, have radical differences in playstyle, but also some striking similarities. The largest similarity, is the presesne of a player acting as a commander for the team. Being a commander compared to being a soldier or a skulk on the front lines is radically different as well. You have to act as the coordinator of your team. You are responsible for keeping an eye on the map, and telling your teammates what needs to be done. NS2 is like an armsrace, where both teams compete to outdamage, outgrow, and eventually overwhelm the other. Playing as a marine, you experience an almost completely different game than as an alien. And because each and every game populated by soley players, no two games are alike. NS2 is not a 'spunk-gargle-weewee 360 noscope FPS'. NS2 is a game of tactics.  Natural Selection looks beautiful. The sci-fi maps, the Darwinism-on-steroids aesthetics of the Kharaa, the sounds, the effects... These all give NS2 this amazing and unique appearance. I have felt true fear when the aliens cut the lights and forced me to engage them in near pitch dark. I have felt the pride swell at being a part of a sucessful push into enemy territory. I have felt the joys of victory, the humility of defeat, and also respect for the enemy team when they manage to outmaneouver us.  The community of Natural Selection 2 is generally friendly and helpful. While there might be a few bad examples here and there, the players are consistantly nice. So long as you're not a caustic individual, you find the community to be one of the strongest aspects of this game.  Get this game. As a fan of the Alien series, this is the game I never recieved. As a fan of deeper games, NS2 has more depth than any probably any other online shooter out there. Thats why I recommend this game. Because this was the kind of game I was always looking for.

After playing this game the first time, I literally said 'F this game.' I constantly got destroyed repeatedly, aliens were literally the hardest thing to get a kill in (outside getting a Onos) and I just didn't understand the game.  After my 'Second' tour of duty, I gave the game more than a 2 hour shot. Looking back on that 2nd shot, I'm happy I did. Once getting past the STEEP learning curve, I was able to hang with pack. No longer getting destroyed everytime I encountered anyone or anything and was able to really appreciate what this game is... RTS mixed with FPS.  It's really a great an idea, you live and die with your commander or hive leader. If you don't listen to their orders, you lose. If you do... you have a fighting chance depending on his skill level. This game requires you to work together otherwise you get dominated by groups. Remember that, cause if you don't... you'll soon learn. With that aspect brought up, I've really felt a sense of accomplishment when we slowly started pushing across the map and constant yelling over the coms to get to the 'Computer Lab, we're under attack there'. Once you arrive in the computer lab, you'll know what this game is about. Cluster F*** of Aliens and Marines just trying to 'win' that one spot for your team. If you win it, you have a sense of 'We did it' but that sense slowly drifts away once the enemy re-directs it attention else where.   You'll have choices to go help that next area or punch them where it hurts and push forward. Sometimes your commander will make the call, other times you have to know whats best for the team. With that being said, I give this game a 8/10 and a recommend buy if at a discounted price. ($25 dollars is a pretty steep cost for the amount of learning curve you have to deal with).
